translated: Commentary on the PrajÃ±ÄpradÄ«pa, Fascicle 4
Verses by Ä€rya NÄgÄrjuna, Commentary by Ä€cÄrya BhÄviveka
Translated by Tripiá¹­aka Master PrabhÄkaramitra of India during the Great Tang
Chapter on the Observation of the Six Faculties, Chapter 3 on the Observation of the Six Faculties. Next, what are the characteristics of establishing this chapter?
In order to refute arising and cause people to recognize the meaning of the absence of intrinsic nature of the six internal sense bases, etc., this chapter is expounded.
Moreover, in order to refute grasping and cause people to penetrate the meaning of the emptiness of the sense bases, etc., this chapter is subsequently composed.
As for the initial analysis, an outsider says:
The arising of the internal sense bases exists in the ultimate truth, and should be accepted in this way.
Why is it so?
Because the objects are definite.
If this arising does not exist, then those definite objects would not exist, just like the child of a barren woman.
Therefore, it should be known that the arising of the internal sense bases exists because their objects are definite.
As a verse says:ğŸ”½The six faculties such as the eyes, ears, nose, tongue,
body, and mind,
Those six sense objects such as form, are the objects according to their number.
The commentary says:
For this reason, the established cause is accomplished, and the meaning of entry and arising is established.
Next, as for discrimination, outsiders definitely say:
There is such going.
Why is it so?
Because it produces results, like seeing form and so forth.
The treatise says:
These two discriminations are now successively refuted.
Those eye faculties and so forth each have dominance, and when they gather they have the ability to grasp form and so forth, and are therefore called faculties.

In the conventional truth, form and so forth can be obtained outside the faculties, because the essence of the doer can be revealed, that is, because it is seen it is called the eye, and up to because it knows it is called the mind.
Furthermore, these faculties and so forth reveal the visible, audible, smellable, tast-able, touchable, and knowable sense objects.
What is the meaning of sense object?
It means that the faculties have the power to grasp the sense objects, and are therefore called sense objects.
There are objects and objects, which exist in the conventional truth.
As for the claim that the faculties and objects definitely exist in the ultimate truth, this is not so, because it contradicts reason.
How can it be revealed to make them understand?
It is like contemplating the eye faculty.
The verse says:
In this way, the eye faculty cannot see its own body,
Since its own body is not seen, how can it see others?
The commentary says:
Why is it not seen?
In this way, in the ultimate truth, the eye faculty cannot be grasped.
Why is this?
The verse says because it does not see its own body and because it has obstruction and because it is form, like the ear and so forth.
Moreover, in the ultimate truth, the eye does not see form.
Why is this?
Because that form arises from causes, like the nose and so forth.
Moreover, because it is included in the form aggregate, like the tongue and so forth.
In this way, in the ultimate truth, form is not the object of the eye.
Why is this?
Because of accumulation, like the nature of the eye itself.
Moreover, in the ultimate truth, form is not the object of the eye.
Why is it so?
Because it is obstructed.
Also because it is derivative form, like the ear and so forth.
Moreover, in the ultimate truth, form is not the object of the eye.
Why is it so?
Because it arises from causes, like the nose and so forth.
Also because it is included in the form aggregate, like the tongue and so forth.
Furthermore, some say:
The eye does not see means it does not see its own nature;
because form is visible, therefore the eye can see form.
The treatise says:
As you say, the eye does not see, assisting me with the power of the reason and example, how can you refute the meaning I have established?
Next, the Abhidharma person says:
If there is no distinction, speaking like this, saying the eye does not see form, this establishes my meaning.
Why is it so?
Because of obtaining one gate.
In my established thesis, the undivided eye does not see form.
If the divided eye does not see form, then the meaning of the scriptures you accept is refuted.
As stated in the verse of my AbhidharmakoÅ›a:
The divided eye sees form, not the consciousness that relies on it.
Isn't this statement in the Abhidharma a refutation of the meaning of the scriptures you accept?
The author says:
If you establish the thesis that this divided eye is meant to see form, this is not correct.
Why is it so?
Because there are no two faults, namely, not being established and then being established again, and not refuting what is intended.
How is it not refuted?
As stated in the verse of the sutra:
The eye does not see form, the mind does not know phenomena,
This is called the supreme truth, which worldly people cannot fathom.
The commentary says:
In the ultimate truth, we do not want to allow the eye to see form, just as it has been extensively refuted before, and this meaning can be established.
Moreover, in the ultimate truth, that partially existing eye cannot see form.
Why is it so?
Because it is the eye faculty, like an eyeless person.
Moreover, in the ultimate truth, that partially existing eye cannot see form.
Why is it so?
Because it is a form faculty, like the ear and so forth.
Moreover, it also does not refute what is understood in the world.
Why is it so?
Because the proposition is different, that is to say, in the ultimate truth, there is no one who can fault it.
Next, in the KÄÅ›mÄ«ri VibhÄá¹£Ä, the proposition is established as follows:
That eye sees various forms, because it can perform the function of seeing.
The treatise says:
As for the reason you give, because it is a part of the proposition, because the logical argument lacks substance, and because it has already been refuted, this meaning is not established.
Moreover, if there is an agent, it contradicts the meaning of establishing a moment, and also because it is different from that without a moment.
This is all unreasonable, therefore the meaning grasped by KÄtyÄyanÄ«putra is not appropriate.
Next, the SautrÄntika says:
Because all conditioned phenomena are without action, the eye cannot see, and the different also cannot be seen.
But the eye and form as conditions, the eye consciousness can arise.
The sÅ«tra says like this, your statement that the eye does not see, is a supererogatory offense.
The treatise says:
Because arising has already been refuted, the eye consciousness cannot be obtained, there is no supererogatory offense.
Moreover, the accepted meaning is also not refuted, that is, accepting the meaning of the sÅ«tra like this, in accordance with worldly truth.
In the ultimate truth, the examination is without substance, having already refuted the two seeings of the eye and form, the visible, etc.
The distinctions of those, the meaning is all unreasonable.
In this way, it is taught to a certain extent in order to cause learners to give rise to various contemplations.
As a previous verse said, In this way, that eye faculty cannot see its own substance;
If it cannot see its own substance, how can it see others?
Because in the ultimate truth, the eye does not see form.
Why is it so?
Because it does not see its own substance, like the ear and so forth.
Some people say:
The eye does not reach the object but can still apprehend form.
Why is it so?
Because that eye faculty can be obtained, like saying the king sees when his servant sees.
The treatise states:
In the ultimate truth, the eye does not reach the object and can apprehend form dust, this is not the case.
Why is it so?
Because the eye cannot apprehend its own substance, like the ear and so forth.
In this way, in the ultimate truth, the apprehended form dust is not the object of the eye faculty that does not reach it.
Why is it so?
Because it is derivative form, like smell and so forth.

Thus, because it is obstructed, arises from causes, is included in the form aggregate, and is also accumulated, these various reasons refute the eye not reaching the object and form not being grasped.
The proposition and example are stated as before, and the two deviant attachments should be examined and understood.
Next, in the ultimate truth, the eye does not not reach the object.
Why is it so?
Because it is a present object, like the nose and so forth.
Some people say:
The eye does not reach the object.
Why is it so?
Because it grasps form with intervals, like the mind.
Moreover, because it can grasp form without effort and with temporal distinctions, and because it grasps beyond the proper measure.
The proposition and example should be understood as before.
The treatise states:
This statement is not so.
Your statement that it does not reach the object means that it grasps form with intervals.
Grasping form with intervals is a part of the proposition and there is no separate meaning, therefore this statement is not so.
Moreover, if time is not distinguished, the meaning of grasping is destroyed.
Even if the real cause is established, it is still not established because there is no substance.
In the ultimate truth, the mind also does not reach, yet it can grasp. This assertion is not established because it contradicts the meaning.
Next, the SÄá¹ƒkhya says:
You say the eye does not grasp objects without reaching them. This establishes what I wish to establish.
Why is it so?
I wish to have the eye reach the object and grasp it.
The treatise says:
The one who grasps without reaching wishes to believe and understand that the eye's nature is empty.
Since the eye's nature is already empty, how can it be established that it reaches the object and grasps it?
You rejoice in vain at the wrong place.
Next, why is it not so that the eye reaches the object and grasps it?
Because it is a faculty, it is like the mind.
It also does not grasp the nose and other faculties, so it is not a one-sided error.
Why is it not a one-sided error?
Because those nose faculties and so forth are also like this, as will be explained later.
Furthermore, if the eye reaches the object, what does this mean?
Is it the intention that the basis takes the object in this way?
This is not so.
Why is it so?
The basis of eye consciousness does not actually go outside.
Why is it so?
Because it is consciousness, like the consciousness of the nose and so forth.
In the ultimate truth, eye consciousness cannot take that object.
Why is it so?
Because it has a cause, like sound and so forth.
The opponent says:
You rely on two gates to refute each other, and relying on this to negate the other, both are not established.
The treatise says:
Because both are without substance, I do not take them. Since I do not take them, the intended meaning is established.
Next, the SÄá¹ƒkhya says:
Because the light of the eye reaches the object, it can take form.
If this is the intention, this is also not so.
In the conventional truth, the light of that eye faculty is also not found.
Why is it so?
Because form is the cause of visual consciousness, it is like form.
Next, the SÄá¹ƒkhya person says:
The eye faculty has light, because of the eye faculty, like the eyes of owls, cats, and other animals.
The treatise says:
The form of the eye faculty is invisible.
Even if one insists that it really has light, then the analogy is not established.
Someone else says:
As stated above, in this way, the eye faculty cannot see its own body. What is the meaning of this?
If dharmas have a self-body that can be seen, then when they combine, others can also see it, like the fragrance of flowers.
By this meaning, the eye does not see itself and also does not see others.
Like the Bodhisattva Devendra's verse in the Hundred Treatise says:
If all those dharmas have a self-body first,
In this way, the eye faculty, how could it not see itself?
The treatise says:
What is the meaning of seeing?
It means that if form is perceived, that form is perceived.
If it is like the eye not existing, and form also being non-existent, then the error of accomplishing what has already been accomplished occurs.
As a verse says:
Consciousness does not reside in the eye or form, nor does it abide between the two,
Neither existent nor non-existent, where does that consciousness reside?
Moreover, if it is said that because there are no seeds of seeing in that eye faculty, therefore it does not see, then the simile of the sumana flower is not correct.
Why is it not correct?
Because the fragrance arises due to the power of the combination of causes and conditions of that flower, just as sesame oil has fragrance due to the combination of kusuma.
No one establishes the meaning of form having seeing, and that refutation is not established.

Moreover, if it is said that because it does not see itself, therefore it also does not see others, then the fire flower simile has no power in both cases, because fire flowers and so forth do not grasp themselves or others, and this is not appropriate.

Thus, since the meaning of the eye seeing is not established, their arising and going are also all not established, because the analogy is without substance and also contradicts the meaning of the cause.
The opponent says:
You say that the eye does not see form because it does not see its own nature. This is the meaning being explained.
If it has no power over its own nature, it is the same for others.
This meaning is not one-sided, just as fire has no power to burn its own nature, but it can for others. The eye is also like this.
The treatise's verse states:
The analogy of fire cannot establish the meaning of the eye seeing.
The commentary states:
In the ultimate truth, the burner is not established. In the conventional truth, fire is not of the nature of seeing.
Moreover, in the conventional truth, the nature of fire itself is not established as having the meaning of burning.
What is called burning?
It refers to the transformation of fuel into fire.
Therefore, it is known that the nature of fire itself is not burning.
Furthermore, the analogy of fire is not established for the meaning of eye seeing. The analogy of the eye seeing fire is as explained before.
How is it already explained?
The verse says:
Already gone, not yet gone, and the time of going have already been generally refuted.
The commentary says:
In the ultimate truth, the already gone, not yet gone, and the time of going have no going, as explained before.
In this way, in the ultimate truth, the already burned, not yet burned, and the time of burning have no burning.
Why is this?
Because of the time of burning, because of the already burned, and because of the not yet burned.
Just as in the time of burning, the already burned, and the not yet burned, the time of burning has two faults.
The already burned is like what has long been burned out.
The not yet burned is originally without burning.
In this way, the already seen, not yet seen, and the time of seeing are not seen.
Why is this?
Because of the already seen, because of the not yet seen, and because of the time of seeing.
It is like the seen, the unseen, and the seeing, which should be refuted in order.
Some say:
The eye has the function of seeing.
Why is it so?
Because it is said in all the treatises that the eye sees various forms.
The treatise states:
This seeing of the eye is explained as a skillful means in the conventional truth, not in the ultimate truth.
How do we know this?
In this treatise, the seeing of the eye is refuted, and therefore the arising of the eye is also refuted. That eye is empty.
As a verse says:
If the eye has not yet seen, it cannot be said to see;
To say that the eye can see, this is not reasonable.
The commentary states:
The meaning of the verse is that the meaning of seeing is not so.
For this reason, as a verse says:
Where there is seeing, there is no seeing; Where there is no seeing, there is also no seeing.
The commentary states:
Because it can see emptiness, like earth, stone, and so forth. The meaning of the verse is like this.
Thus, these two kinds of seeing and the agent, this meaning is not so. Therefore, the verse says, Seeing then has no seeing, non-seeing also has no seeing, both are prohibited.
It is like if there is or is not, the conditions are all useless.
Thus, if there is or is not, the cause is also prohibited in the same way.
Furthermore, the SÄá¹ƒkhyas and VaiÅ›eá¹£ikas say:
Because this eye sees the instruments of action, that which possesses the eye is called the seer.
Because the seer sees with his own eye, like the wood that is cut, the cutter can cut, not the axe can cut.
Therefore, the eye is not the seer, this then accomplishes what I have accomplished.
That is to say, the agent has various instruments of action, because of the instruments of action, like an axe and so forth, there must be a cutter.
The treatise says:
Those false discriminations that say there is a seer, this attachment is not so.
As a verse says:
If you have already refuted seeing, you should understand that the seer is refuted.
The commentary says:
Just as the eye does not see itself, so it is with that [seer].
The meaning of a person's own essence seeing a person is not so, because it contradicts what is done in the world, like a knife not cutting itself, and so on.
How is it known through inference?
It means that in the ultimate truth, that person has no meaning of seeing.
Why is it so?
Because it does not see its own essence, like the ear and so on.

It is also not the case that the meaning of the reason is not established. In that sÅ«tra, when it says I see myself, it merely establishes the name of self on the basis of the mind, and speaks of it in the conventional truth, not in the ultimate truth.
Because it is an object, because it is an object of cognition, because it is a measure.
Like sound and the ear, these reasons and their examples should be explained in detail.
Furthermore, in the ultimate truth, form is not seen as a self.
Why is it so?
Because of being an object, like my own body cannot see itself.
In this way, the objects of cognition and so forth should be explained in detail.
The opponent says:
In the Buddha's teachings, there is no self.
You say that my own body cannot see itself, which contradicts the teachings.
The treatise says:
In the conventional truth, the metaphor of the self is provisionally spoken of, and does not contradict the teachings.
In the ultimate truth, the axe and the metaphor are both without substance, so it is not the case that what is already established is established again.
Some people say:
You say that the seer does not see, which contradicts your own words.
Why is it so?
If you say it is the seer, how can you say it does not see?
If you say it does not see, how can you call it the seer?
This is a fallacy in your argument.
The treatise says:
The dharma of dependent origination does not arise, as has already been answered before, and will not be discussed again.
Furthermore, you say the seer, is it seeing its own substance?
Or is it not seeing?
If it is said that the self sees itself, like the SÄá¹ƒkhya claim that thought is the self of the person,
if the seer is the seeing of the self, the self is not an agent, and apart from the eye faculty it should be able to see.
Moreover, if the cutter is apart from the axe it cannot cut, how can the person apart from the eye see?
I say that the seer and the cutter exist in the conventional truth, not in the ultimate truth.
In order to analyze this, the verse says:
Apart from the eye, not apart from the eye, the seer cannot be found.
The commentary says:
When the eye and other faculties did not exist in the past and when they are abandoned, there is no eye.
If there is no eye, then the seen and the seer are empty.
Apart from the seen and the seer, to grasp that there is a seer is not correct.
Seeing has no intrinsic nature, and the seer also does not exist. The meaning is like this.
Moreover, if it is said that like the nature of fire, the seer is also like this, this is not correct.
Why is this?
Because when there is no fuel, fire has no substance.
Next, the Saá¹ƒkhya person says:
If the eye is not separated from this form, it can be obtained. The examination shows that there is a seer who can see.
This attachment is not correct.
Why is this?
Because there is no seer.
That form can be obtained means that the eye, form, space, light, and attention, these being present, there is form that can be obtained.
Moreover, when these conditions are complete and gathered, it is said that Devadatta is called the seer. There is no such thing as the person conceived by the Saá¹ƒkhyas called the seer.
Why is this?
Because there are no blind people who can see form.
The eye that can see is called the seer, just as a lamp, without thought, is also the cause of light. The seeing of the eye is also like this.
For this reason, in the conventional truth, there is also no seer.
Next, the VaiÅ›eá¹£ika says:
The seer has no substance, because the color consciousness arises from the combination of the four elements. Therefore, it is called the seer sees.
The treatise states:
That is the same as the previous error. The combination of the four elements has a separate seer, but the world does not know it. To say it exists is not reasonable.
Therefore, the verse says:
Apart from the eye, there is no seer, because it has no self-nature.
Apart from the eye, there is no seeing. The general term seer is used according to your intention.
Furthermore, the VaiÅ›eá¹£ika establishes that in the ultimate truth, the seer sees form.
This is unreasonable.
Why is it so?
Because it is different from the eye, like a pot, etc. The seer is not established by the previous two methods.
Furthermore, the distinction of the person as the seer is not reasonable, because it has no self-nature.
As the verse says:ğŸ”½Apart from the eye, not apart from the eye, the seer cannot be found.
The self-nature of the seer cannot be seen, whether it has eyes or not.
If you say that the seer has eyes that can see, this is also not so.
Why is it so?
Because the eyes have substance, seeing form can be accomplished, just as fire can burn.
The seeing of the eyes is also like this. In the conventional truth, it should be understood in this way.
If apart from the eyes there is a separate seer, even a blind person without eyes should be able to see, but this is not so.
Next, the VaiÅ›eá¹£ikas say:
The seer should be able to see form by performing the function. It should be understood in this way, because it possesses the instrument of action.
If it does not perform, then that instrument of action would not exist, like space.
Because there is the instrument of the eyes, with the function of seeing form, it is known that there is a seer and that seeing is performed.
The treatise states:
In the ultimate truth, at all times the eyes do not exist, so positing a seer is not so.
As a verse says:
Because the seer does not exist, both the agent and object are empty.
The commentary states:
If the seer has no substance, then there is nothing to grasp.
To say that the eye is the instrument, and that the seer sees with this eye, this is not reasonable.
Therefore, your statement that the instrument exists because of the action, that reason is unestablished, and it also contradicts the meaning, the fault is like this.
Next, the followers of one's own vehicle say:
The conditions of the conditioned are empty because they depend on others. The eye and the self both cannot see. This meaning should be so.
To say that the seen and the seer are completely without substance, this meaning is not so.
Why is it so?
Because the four kinds of effects such as consciousness, etc. exist.
If this were not so, then consciousness, contact, feeling, and craving would not be called effects, like a person born blind.
The treatise says:
The seen and the seeing, this meaning is not established, as it has been refuted before.
Now what is meant is, as a verse says:
Because the seen and the seer do not exist, the four kinds such as consciousness do not exist.
The commentary says:
Why is it nonexistent?
Because the conditions do not exist.
For this reason, consciousness and so forth are not established.
Since the subject and object are not established, the analogy also has no substance.
Some say:
In the ultimate truth, there is consciousness and so forth, because the effects such as grasping have substance.
The treatise states:
This should be answered like this.
The verse states:
Where can the effects such as grasping and conditions be obtained?
The commentary states:
Because consciousness and so forth do not exist, grasping is also not established. The meaning of the verse is like this.
Grasping is the meaning of appropriation. How many kinds does it have?
Namely, grasping at desire, grasping at precepts, grasping at self-existence, and grasping at views.
Those graspings give rise to existence, birth, aging, and death. Such faults always follow you.
At the beginning of the outsider's chapter, they cite analogies and so forth to establish that the eyes see, as previously refuted.
The ears, sounds, and so forth are also refuted in the same way as before.
As a verse states:
Ear, nose, tongue, body, and mind, what is heard and the hearer, etc.,
One should know that this meaning is all the same as the refutation of seeing with the eyes.
Next, at the beginning of the chapter, the opponent said that there is going because of being the doer of an effect.
This is also not so, as stated in the previous verse.
Therefore, going has no nature, and the goer is also thus. The time of going and all dharmas are all nonexistent.
For this reason, the opponent's discrimination that there is the arising of entry and the meaning of going is all unestablished, as explained previously.
By means of the emptiness of the essence of entry, etc., it generates faith and understanding. The meaning of the chapter is like this, and therefore it is established.
As stated in the Speechless Sutra (Anavatapta-sutra) in verse:
The inner and outer earth element is nondual. The wisdom of the Tathagata is able to realize this.
That nonduality and non-nonduality, the single characteristic and the characteristic of nonexistence are known thus.
Also, as stated in the Sutra of the Golden-Light Girl:
MaÃ±juÅ›rÄ« said to the girl:
'You should contemplate the various realms.'
The girl replied:
'MaÃ±juÅ›rÄ«!
It is like when the eon is burned, so too are the three realms.'
And spoke a verse, saying:
'The eye cannot see forms, the mind does not know dharmas,
This is the unsurpassed truth, the world cannot understand.'
As the PrajÃ±ÄpÄramitÄ SÅ«tra says:
All those dharmas are unknowable and unseen, and the Dharma teacher who expounds them is also unobtainable.
They cannot be discriminated by the mind, nor can they be known by the intellect.
As the Buddha Mother SÅ«tra says:
Sister!
The eye does not see forms, and the mind does not know dharmas.
In this way, because enlightenment is detached, the eye and form are detached, and so on up to because enlightenment is detached, the mind and dharmas are detached.
It is also as the Buddha told the bodhisattva Ultimate Courage:
Good man!
Form does not become the realm of form, feeling, perception, formation, or consciousness does not become the realm of consciousness, because the realm does not exist.
Ultimate Courage!
Form does not know form, form does not see form.
If form does not know or see, this is prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ;
Up to feeling, perception, formation, and consciousness not knowing or seeing is also like this.
The chapter on contemplating the faculties is finished.

Chapter 4: Contemplating the Aggregates, Commentary on the PrajÃ±ÄpradÄ«pa Treatise, Contemplating the Aggregates Next, in order to make one understand the meaning of the absence of nature in the aggregates, this chapter exists.
Some people say:
In the ultimate truth, there are the sense bases and so forth.
Why is it so?
Because they are included in the aggregates.
If they do not exist, then form, the sense bases, and so forth would not be included in the aggregates, like empty space and flowers.
Because the sense bases exist, they are included in the aggregates, just as the ten kinds of form sense bases are included in the form aggregate;
The dharma-Äyatana is included in three aggregates, namely feeling, perception, and formation, and is also included in part of the form aggregate.
That manas-Äyatana is included in the consciousness aggregate.
For this reason, in the ultimate truth there are the sense bases and so forth.
The treatise states:
The form aggregate is briefly said to be of two kinds:
The four great elements and the derivative form.
If all distinctions such as the three times are generally spoken of as the form aggregate.
That eye and so forth are included in the aggregates, the opponent wishes to use as a reason, form is coarse and easy to understand, so it is explained first.
As a verse states:
If apart from the cause of form, form cannot be obtained.
The commentary states:
What are those causes of form?
They are the four great elements such as earth.
In the ultimate truth, if apart from these, form cannot be obtained.
But in the conventional truth, form is provisionally established based on the cause of the four great elements.
In the ultimate truth, form is examined to be unreal, because its own cause is not accepted and because that cognition is without substance.
If the self-cause is not accepted and the cognition has no essence, then it does not truly exist, like an army and so forth.
The cause of form cannot be grasped, and the cognition of form has no essence, it is also like this.
Furthermore, in the ultimate truth, the essence of the object of form cognition does not truly exist.
Why is it so?
Because it is a cognition, like the cognition of a forest and so forth.
Furthermore, in the ultimate truth, the object of the term form does not truly exist.
Why is it so?
Because it is heard, like the sound of an army and so forth.
If it is said that the aggregates such as feeling are not unilaterally [non-existent], this is not so.
Why is it so?
Because the mental factors such as consciousness are also refuted together, they are not unilaterally [non-existent].
Or it may be said that in the ultimate truth there is that real form.
Why is it so?
Because the cognition of the transformation of that form is not separate.
If the object changes and the cognition also differs, this is conventionally existent, like a pot and so forth. Just as the cognition of blue does not differ at different times.
For this reason, we know that there is real form.
The treatise states:
Because in ultimate truth, the examination has no substance.
Having examined derived form, next we refute the four great elements.
As a verse states:
If one were to depart from form, the cause of form would also not be seen.
The commentary states:
Form, sound, smell, taste, touch, and so forth, these causal forms are all separate. Therefore, the causal elements such as earth cannot be seen or grasped.
For this reason, the author of the treatise first refutes earth.
What is the reason for refuting earth and so forth?
Because there is a great meaning.
What is the great meaning?
In the conventional truth, that which arises from causes is in reality unborn in ultimate truth.
This has no intrinsic nature, as stated in the Laá¹…kÄvatÄra SÅ«tra:
Apart from accumulation, there is no substance. That cognition has nothing to grasp.
Therefore, I know dependent origination is empty. I say it has no intrinsic nature.
No thing arises from conditions. No thing ceases from conditions.
Arising is only the arising of conditions. Cessation is only the cessation of conditions.
The commentary says:
By this method, in the ultimate truth, earth does not really exist. In this way, it is certain that their cause cannot be seen. Because it is not seen.
If it is not seen because it cannot be seen, then in the ultimate truth, it does not really exist, like an army and so forth.
Furthermore, in the ultimate truth, the substance of the object of the cognition of earth does not really exist.
Why is it so?
Because it is a cognition, like the cognition of a forest and so forth.
Furthermore, in the ultimate truth, the object of the meaning of the word earth does not really exist.
Why is it so? Because it is heard, like the sound of an army and so forth.
Furthermore, in the ultimate truth, the self-combined parts do not have that different color.
Why is it so?
Because it cannot be grasped, and that cognition is without substance, like the self-nature of earth and so forth.
Next, the SÄá¹ƒkhya says:
You say that form and so forth are not different from earth and so forth, this proves what I am trying to prove.
The treatise says:
Because it refutes difference, it is not by non-difference that you can understand.
Because I do not accept the mistaken discrimination of non-difference that you speak of.
Next, the VaiÅ›eá¹£ika says:
Your reason is not one-sided.
Why is it so?
Just as when a lamp is not grasped, there is no cognition of a pot, because they are different.
The treatise says:
You speak unskillfully. I only refute that because the self-combined parts cannot be grasped, that cognition is without substance, not discussing other matters.
Although a lamp is without substance, there are the lights of jewels, herbs, the sun, moon, and so forth, and the cognition of that pot arises.
Apart from the combined parts, no other color can be obtained.
For this reason, your analogy is not appropriate, because the lamp is not the same as the pot in terms of being composed of combined parts.
The absence of a separate entity is not a fallacy of non-uniqueness.
As a verse says:
It is not reasonable for this thing to be different from that thing.
The explanation says:
This meaning will be discussed later.
Moreover, in the ultimate truth, the difference between the lamp and the pot is also not established.
For this reason, it is not a fallacy of non-uniqueness.
Next, the VaiÅ›eá¹£ika says:
The general reality of the army, etc. exists because it arises at the beginning.
Your statement that earth, etc. do not exist in reality, the proof you give to make others understand, the analogy is not established.
The treatise states:
The various parts of the army are not the cause for the general reality of the army to arise at the beginning.
Why is it so?
Because it is general, like the various parts of a tree such as the roots, trunk, branches, leaves, etc.
The various parts of that army, such as elephants, are not the initial cause of that army.
Why is it so?
Because they are not parts, like a cloth and so forth.
Nor is there a lack of substance in similes, as stated in the verse:
If one departs from form, the cause of form is also not seen.
As previously stated, the reason and simile verify that form and so forth are not different from earth and so forth, and that earth and so forth are not different from form and so forth.
Difference is refuted as before, and non-difference is refuted later.
If they are not different, milk is precisely yogurt, and yogurt is also milk, because they are not different.
For this reason, this proof is established.
As stated in the Laá¹…kÄvatÄra SÅ«tra:
Non-difference has no substance, like bundles of reeds or separate places.
Whether one or different, ordinary beings falsely discriminate.
The commentary states:
Like form and sense faculties, they wish to establish by saying that the cause exists.
The reason is not established, and it also contradicts the meaning.
Moreover, if you discriminate that form exists apart from the cause of form, this is also not so.
Why is it so?
Because there is a fault.
As a verse says:
If form exists apart from the cause of form, form would then fall into having no cause.
The explanation says:
Those who speak of having no cause say that they want to make form exist without a cause.
They should be asked like this:
Even if you say it accords with reason, what kind of thing is the kind that you say has no cause?
They do not want it to be so, as a verse says:
A thing existing without a cause is never possible.
The explanation says:
What does this mean?
Because there is no analogy to illustrate its substance. If one denies causation, there is a great fault.
This assertion is not established, as it has already been refuted in the chapter on contemplating conditions.
The SÄá¹ƒkhya says:
In the ultimate truth, earth and so forth truly exist, because form and so forth are not different, just like the essence of form itself.
The treatise states:
Your reason is unestablished, and the example is also non-existent.
Because form and so forth being not different and the essence of form itself have already been refuted.
Again, someone says:
In the ultimate truth, there is earth and so forth.
Why is it so?
Because their effect exists.
If this were non-existent, their effect would not exist, like the flowers in the sky.
Now, because the effect form exists, earth and so forth are not non-existent.
This assertion is not correct. As a verse says:
If the cause exists apart from form, then this cause would be without effect;
How could there be the meaning of a cause existing without an effect?
The commentary states:
If the cause of form exists apart from the effect of form, then it would be a cause without an effect.
Why is it so?
Because it is different, like bamboo strips and so forth.
Moreover, that cause is also a collection of form and so forth.
For this reason, cause and effect are not established.
As you say, because the effect exists, the cause contradicts the meaning, so this assertion is not established.
Moreover, analyzing whether this form exists or not, both are unreasonable, because the cause is useless.
As a verse says:
If form already exists, it does not depend on the cause of form;
If form did not exist before, it also does not depend on the cause of form.
The explanation says:
If form already exists, then it does not need a cause.
Why is it so? Because it exists, like a pot or clothing.
If form did not exist before, it is simply non-existent, like other things. The meaning is like this.
Moreover, the assertion of no cause means that the cause has no substance.
This is unreasonable, as a verse says:
Form existing without a cause is unreasonable.
The explanation says:
In the conventional truth, form without a cause is also not so.
Moreover, the VaibhÄá¹£ikas say:
The existence of future form is answered by the same verse as before.
Moreover, in the conventional truth, form that has not yet taken its effect is without substance.
To say that it exists is not reasonable.
For this reason, grasping the existence of the four great elements and derivative form at all times contradicts the meaning.
As a verse says:
Therefore, with regard to the realm of form, one should not give rise to discrimination.
The commentary says:
What is discrimination?

It refers to the discrimination of the existence of real form, or the non-difference of cause and effect, and the form-cause of earth and so forth, such as the distinctions in shape and appearance of form and so forth.
With regard to this object, one should not discriminate, because one cannot avoid the previously stated errors.
Those who wish to attain true non-discriminating cognition and the eye of wisdom should carefully contemplate that just as what is seen in a dream is not so upon awakening, so is that cognition.
Again, someone says:

The power of the prior cause, in the succession of continuity, is also seen when the subsequent effect arises, just as when a white cloth is dyed with the juice of the madder plant, due to the impregnation, in the succession of continuity, the color is obtained when the subsequent effect is reached.
In order to refute this grasping, it is said in the verse:
If the effect resembles the cause, this is not so.
The explanation says:
This inference refutes that it is not the cause of that effect, the meaning of the statement is like this.
Why is it so?
In the ultimate truth, one does not wish to make that blue-colored cloth the cause of the blue-colored cloth, because of similarity, like the other blue cloths, etc.
The Saá¹ƒkhya person says:
Your statement that the cause of the other blue cloth is also non-existent is not so.
Why is it so?
You establish a metaphor because it has no substance.
The treatise says:
You speak unskillfully.
When that cloth arises, this cause is not a part of it, because it does not produce that cloth. Such a metaphor is established.
Next, a person of our own school says:

There are similar causes and effects, and dissimilar causes and effects. Although there are differences in the world between the previous and later moments, within the category of things, like the arising and ceasing of the flame of a wind-blown lamp, this is called similar causes and effects.
Like burning wood to become ash, or transforming milk into yogurt, etc., this is called dissimilar causes and effects.
The treatise says:
Those similar causes and effects are like what has been refuted earlier.
As for the dissimilar ones, they are now refuted.
A verse says:
If the effect is not similar to the cause, the meaning should also not be so.
The commentary says:
In the ultimate truth, this grain seed is not a cause for the sprout.
Why is it so?
Because they are not similar, like broken pottery.
Or it is said that rice grains are the cause of sprouts, because when grains exist, sprouts can exist, and can be pointed out, like the sound of a great drum and wheat sprouts, etc.
The treatise says:
You speak unskillfully.
Because all that arises is refuted.
Because the analogy is without substance, and what is established is insufficient, this error exists.
If it is said that the eye faculty, etc. give rise to the effect of consciousness, etc., this is not similar, because it is not unilaterally so, this is also not so.
Why is it so?
Because like refuting all dharmas, those eye consciousnesses, etc. are also thus refuted, because there is no other method, therefore it is not the error of not being unilaterally so.
As previously stated, because the effect exists when there is real earth, etc., both are not established, because it contradicts the meaning.
Next, the VaibhÄá¹£ika says:
Because there is a cause of production, that is, when conditioned dharmas arise, all similar and dissimilar dharmas are their causes. The analogy is without substance.
The treatise states:
You speak unskillfully, because there is discrimination.
The cause of production, such as the specific nature, co-arising, and so forth, has already been refuted.
From the beginning of this chapter, these words have refuted the four great elements and their derivative form, causing others to understand that the form aggregate is without substance.
As for the remaining aggregates of feeling and so forth, it is as a verse states:
The aggregate of feeling, the aggregate of thought, and the aggregates of perception and mental formations of all kinds,
Dharmas such as these are all refuted in the same way as the aggregate of form.
The commentary states:
Just as the aggregate of form is refuted, so too are feeling and the others.

It has already been explained that form does not truly exist in the ultimate truth, because its own causes are not grasped, and because the cognition of it is without substance, like a collection of soldiers and so forth.
In this way, in the ultimate truth, feeling, thought, contact, attention, etc. are all not really existent, because their own causes are not grasped, and they also do not grasp, like an army, etc.
All should be understood in this way.
Moreover, the causes of feeling, etc., namely contact, form, light, space, attention, etc., should be refuted in this way as appropriate.
Moreover, just as the causes of form, etc. are not separate, it has already been made understood to others.
In this way, in the ultimate truth, the causes of feeling, etc. are also not different, because the parts of their own combination cannot be grasped.
They should not grasp like their own causes and their own substance, and this error should be explained as before.
If the opponent makes an error, he should avoid it as before.

Moreover, these dharmas refer to the distinctions of conditioned dharmas outside the aggregates, like vases, clothes, etc., because they really exist and are different.Here is the corrected and aligned text:

As appropriate, they are the same as the refutation of form. If you say that form and so forth are included in the aggregates, therefore they are causes, this reason is unestablished, the analogy is also non-existent, because the meaning of the aggregates is destroyed.
That which is included in the aggregates is included in the conventional truth, not in the ultimate truth, because it contradicts the meaning of the reason.
This principle should be understood in this way.

Moreover, some people imagine and discriminate that in the ultimate truth, the self-nature of any existent is not empty, and that arising, ceasing, and so forth occur. The meaning of all these disputes is not correct.
Why is it so?
Because when truly and accurately contemplated, their characteristics are empty.
In the ultimate truth, the sense bases do not arise, and their essence does not truly exist. Such contemplation causes people to recognize and understand this.
If one grasps the non-empty and makes it a fault of emptiness, this is also not so.
Why is it so?
Because it is the same as the previous refutation.
All are unable to make faults for emptiness, as a verse says:
If one observes the essence of one thing, then one sees the essence of all things;
In this way, one thing is empty, and all are empty because of it.
The commentary says:

The previous passages refute the arising of the sense bases. By understanding that the aggregates have no intrinsic nature, the practitioner is enlightened. The meaning of the chapter is like this, and therefore it is established.
As the Buddha told the bodhisattva Supreme Courage:
Good man!
Because form has no arising or ceasing, feeling, perception, mental formations, and consciousness also have no arising or ceasing.
If those five aggregates have no arising and no ceasing, this is prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ.
Good man!
Form is apart from the intrinsic nature of form, and in the same way, feeling, perception, mental formations, and consciousness are apart from the intrinsic nature of consciousness.
If the intrinsic natures of form up to consciousness are apart, this is prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ.
Good man!
Because form has no intrinsic nature, feeling, perception, mental formations, and consciousness also have no intrinsic nature.
If form up to consciousness have no intrinsic nature, this is prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ.
It is also like the verse in the SÅ«tra of the Questions of the BrahmÄ God Supreme Thought:
I speak of the aggregates for the world, those aggregates are the basis for that world,
But one who does not make the aggregates a basis, that person is liberated from worldly dharmas.
The world is like the characteristic of empty space, that characteristic of empty space is also non-existent,
By understanding thus, there is nothing to rely on, the eight worldly dharmas cannot defile.
Moreover, as the VajracchedikÄ PrajÃ±ÄpÄramitÄ SÅ«tra says:
SubhÅ«ti!
Bodhisattvas do not dwell in form when practicing generosity, they do not dwell in sound, smell, taste, touch, or dharmas when practicing generosity.
As a verse from the Laá¹…kÄvatÄra SÅ«tra says:
The three existences are provisionally established, because things have no intrinsic nature,ğŸ”½But within provisional establishment,
one gives rise to discrimination through false imagination.
When one awakens to discrimination, the intrinsic nature cannot be obtained,
Because there is no intrinsic nature, those words are also non-existent.
Such sÅ«tras should be explained in detail here.
The explanation of the chapter on contemplating the five aggregates is completed.
Chapter 5: Contemplating the Six Elements, Commentary on the PrajÃ±ÄpradÄ«pa, Contemplating the Six Elements Next, all dharmas are without essence because of being refuted by emptiness.
Now, wanting to clarify the meaning of the lack of intrinsic nature of the various elements such as earth, this chapter arises.
What is the meaning of this?
In the contemplation of the aggregates, it is said that if apart from form, there is no cause for form.
Here, the school itself again cites the Buddha's words as evidence, as the sÅ«tra says:
The Buddha told the great king:
There are six kinds of elements:
Earth, water, fire, wind, space, and consciousness, each with its own characteristics, namely solidity, fluidity, heat, motion, containment, and cognition.
These six elements are called a person.

If it were like positing the existence of nonexistent empty flowers, and grasping that as a person, this would not be correct. Therefore, the previously established thesis by the proponent that the substance of the causes of earth and other forms does not exist would be destroyed, and also because it would contradict the scriptures.
The treatise states:
For the sake of conventional truth, the TathÄgata teaches these six elements such as earth to be a person, not in the ultimate truth.
Furthermore, the VaibhÄá¹£ika says:
In the ultimate truth, there are the elements such as earth.
Why is it so?
Because their characteristics exist.
If these elements such as earth were truly nonexistent, the TathÄgata would not speak of their characteristics, like the flowers in the sky.
Now there is solidity and so forth as the characteristics of earth and so forth. Because the characteristics exist, earth and so forth are not nonexistent.
The treatise states:ğŸ”½Space has no self-nature and requires little effort to generate understanding in others, because it is not a thing.
Having understood the element of space, the remaining elements are then easily refuted.
As a verse says:
First, space does not exist, and space has no characteristics of even a hair tip.
The commentary says:
Space and the characteristic of unobstructedness are no different. The meaning of the verse is like this.
Furthermore, the VaibhÄá¹£ika says:
We establish this meaning of unobstructedness as the characteristic of space, because that characteristic exists.
The treatise says:
This unobstructedness established as existent, others are unable to understand.
What is the meaning of this?
Just as impermanent sound is the proposition, because of impermanence it is taken as the reason. In the same way, this space exists, because space exists.
This then has only the proposition, no reason or example, and the meaning is not established.

If you think that the unobstructed characteristic is space, in the conventional truth it is understood by people, and there is no need to explain the reason for others to understand it, because in the ultimate truth this is not established, so it is definitely necessary to explain the reason for others to understand it.
If they explain it, then there is the fault of reason and example, because there is only the proposition.
Next, the VaibhÄá¹£ika says:
Space really exists, it is an unconditioned dharma.
In order to answer this, the verse says:
Here, space is examined, not even a hair's breadth of reality exists.
The commentary says:
In the ultimate truth, space is not real.
Why is it so?
Because it is unborn, like the horns of a rabbit.
In this way, because the reason lacks substance, because the result does not exist, because it does not exist, and so on, all the reasons should be explained in detail like this.
Next, the VaiÅ›eá¹£ika says:
Because the characterized and the characteristic are different.
The treatise says:
If so, then they would have priority and posteriority, like pots, clothes, and so on.
In order to answer this, the verse says:
If space existed before, space would be without characteristics.
The meaning of the verse is as follows:
Space is without characteristics.
Here it is said that space is not characterized by those characteristics.
Why is it so?
Because it existed before, like any given thing.
Moreover, non-obstruction is not the characteristic of space.
Why is it so?
Because it is different, like any given thing.
Moreover, if it is said that the characterized and the characteristic are without characteristics, this is also not so.
Why is it so?
Because I also abandon the distinction of difference.
Moreover, if you say that the cause in conventional truth is not established as a cause, you cannot avoid the fault of contradicting the meaning.
Therefore, the characteristics of difference and non-difference are both not established. Therefore, it is known that space is definitely without characteristics.
If you say that the formless has substance, people cannot understand it.
Therefore, it is as the verse says:
There is no place where a single thing exists without form and with substance.
The explanation says:
If in the ultimate truth, this substance is established either by itself or by other parts, the meaning is not so.
Some people say:
The characterized empty space has such a substance, and there is the ability to transform in it.
This is also not so, as the verse says:
Since the substance without characteristics is already non-existent, where does the characteristic transform?
The explanation says:
Because the basis is non-existent, the dependent is also non-existent. Since the meaning is not established, it is again an error of the reason.
Furthermore, if the characterized and the characteristic are not different, how can the characterized still characterize the characterized?
Because the different characteristics are non-existent.
For this reason, in the non-different gate, empty space is without characteristics.
If you say that the characteristics are different from the gateway, they are also not characteristics, because the characterized is different, just like any single thing, etc.
Thus, since the characteristics are already without substance, emptiness is also without characteristics. Therefore, the verse says, There is no substance without characteristics, referring to space.
Where do the characteristics operate? Because they do not operate there.
This meaning should be understood.
Moreover, a verse says:
The characteristics of the absence of characteristics do not operate, and the characteristics of the presence of characteristics do not operate.
The commentary says:
The meaning of characteristics and the characterized that you speak of are all unreasonable.
Why is it so?
If there is a characteristic of a nonexistent thing, this is not established;
it is the same for an existent substance.
A verse says:
Apart from the presence of characteristics and the absence of characteristics, it also does not operate in a different place.
The commentary says:
In the ultimate truth, if there is a substance whose characteristics operate within it, this is all unreasonable.
Why is it so?
Because the meaning that the opponent wishes to prove by means of the non-existence of examples is not established.
Moreover, like the flowers in the sky, because they are without characteristics, their characteristics are also like that.

Because they are without substance, they cannot be said to transform. This is understood by the world. Therefore, the verse says that the characteristics of existence do not transform, because in the ultimate truth, they are like experiments.
That which is unobstructed is not the characteristic of space.
Why is it so?
Because it has characteristics, like the characteristics of solidity, etc.
Moreover, some say:
The characteristics of existent and non-existent things transform within them, and this is not a fault.
In order to refute that, the verse says, Apart from existence and non-existence, it also does not transform elsewhere. Both of these are not correct.
The definite contemplator will extensively refute this later in the chapter on Fuel and the Burning.
First, causing others to understand the faults of the two parts now reverts to you, because this is not appropriate, as it has two faults.
Moreover, some say:
In the ultimate truth, space exists, because it has characteristics.
If it did not exist, its characteristics would not be mentioned, like the flowers in the sky.
As a sutra says, the Buddha told the great king:
These six elements are called a person.
Therefore, it exists, and because it has characteristics.
The treatise says:
The characterized is not established, because I have already refuted it before.
As a verse says:
Because the characterized is not established, the characteristic also is not established.
The explanation says:
Because the characteristic also falls into the characterized, the characteristic is also not established. The analogy is without substance.
For this reason, with wisdom and careful observation, both the characterized and the characteristic are not established.
As a verse says:
Therefore, there is no characterized, and there is also no characteristic.
The explanation says:
Because it causes others to understand that the substance to be examined does not exist.
By this examination, it is known that it truly does not exist, and this meaning is established.
Next, the VaibhÄá¹£ikas say:
According to our established doctrine, space has substance.
Why is it so?
Because it is the object of the desire to eliminate defilements, like form;
and because it is the object of samÄdhi, like consciousness;
and because it is also unconditioned, like nirvÄá¹‡a.
The treatise says:
If you want to establish that space exists in the ultimate truth, is it the characterized or the characteristic?
Both are unreasonable, as explained above, causing people to understand.
Therefore, the verse says:
Apart from the characterized and the characteristic, its substance also does not exist.
The commentary says:
The meaning of the school is like this. The other nirvÄá¹‡as and so forth, each substance that can be established, all are not established as analogies.
Next, a different school says:
Space exists because it receives its own substance, and also because it is conditioned.
The meaning and reason are both unestablished, as the previously examined faults should be explained in this way.
Next, the Sutra master says:
As I establish the meaning, the absence of real obstruction in space is called space. Space has no substance and is only a provisional name. My meaning is like this.
The treatise says:

As the VaibhÄá¹£ika masters say, because it is the object of samÄdhi, it becomes the object of desire and attachment. In order to eliminate desire, it is established that space has substance in order to make people understand.
Now the SautrÄntika doctrine says that the absence of real obstruction in space is called space, and it is only a provisional name. It denies the previous existence of substance.
Those who make such calculations make my analogy even more obvious.
Now this meaning is explained, as in the verse:
It is not reasonable for form to exist apart from the cause of form.
Because form originally has no substance, how can non-substance be established?
The commentary says:
As explained earlier in the chapter on contemplating the aggregates, the principle that form with obstruction exists in the ultimate truth is untenable.
As the sutra distinguishes space as having no substance, this argument does not hold.
Some say:
The substance of space is not understood by people, as there is no analogy for it.
I now establish the principle to make it easy for people to understand, and should explain it thus: the substance of form and so forth exists, because their non-substance is observed.
If this exists, their substance is observed to be non-existent, like the two non-substances of form and taste.
If a dharma has no substance, it is not observed to be non-existent, like the horns of a horse.
The treatise states:
The substance of form dharmas has already been refuted by me.
I do not wish to make you accept their non-substance, as stated in the verse:
There is no substance.
The commentary states:
The name of form.
The verse states:
Where?
The commentary states:
Because of taste.
The verse states:
Can something without substance be apprehended?
The explanation is:
Because that form does not exist, the analogy is without substance, and the intended meaning is destroyed, one should understand.
The opponent says:
Both existence and non-existence exist, because their understanding exists.
If the understanding exists, then those things exist.
The treatise states:
You say that the understanding understands existence and non-existence. Does this understanding have substance?
Or is it without substance?
Both have already been refuted. The understanding having substance, this meaning is not established.
Moreover, because it is not similar to existence and non-existence.
Apart from this, the understanding is discriminated, but this meaning is not so.
As a verse says:
Apart from substance and non-substance, where is there an understanding?
The explanation is:
The understanding is without substance, the meaning of the verse is like this.
The opponent further says:
I have a different approach to make this distinction, as such an understanding is dissimilar to their view of having substance and not having substance.
The treatise states:
That which is dissimilar in substance and has two parts is unreasonable, because it contradicts observation. There is no valid cognition that can make people believe and understand this.
Thus, when carefully examining space, it is not reasonable. As a verse states:
Therefore, one should know that space is neither with substance nor without substance,
Neither the characterized nor the characteristic, and the remaining five are the same as space.
The commentary states:
Just as refuting space with not even a trace of substance can make people accept it, the remaining five are also like this.
As a verse states:
First, earth and so forth have not even a trace of characteristics that can be obtained.
The commentary states:
Earth, water, and so forth should also be extensively distinguished in this way.
Up to the verse says: Not substance, not non-substance, not the characterized, not the characteristic, should be refuted like space.
What is called realm?
The meaning of storehouse is the meaning of realm, like that gold realm.
Because those space, etc. can be the storehouse of worry, suffering, etc.

Moreover, the meaning of holding one's own characteristics effortlessly is the meaning of realm. Those who speak of those realms do so in order to teach and transform sentient beings, out of compassion. Those who speak of the Buddha's words are included in the conventional truth. In the ultimate truth, realms have no substance, and entry is also not established.
Because realms exist, what is desired is not destroyed.
Moreover, some people say:

If in the ultimate truth all the meanings of sentences are denied, this is the teaching of the LokÄyata school's wrong views, spoken in a way similar to the Buddha's words. This should be abandoned, because it is not the Buddha's words.
The treatise says:
You give rise to excessive faults, falsely denying real hair, fur, mosquitoes, flies, etc.
What is the meaning of this?
I say that entering into cessation is to cease having a self-nature, not to say that there is no self-nature.
As a verse from the Laá¹…kÄvatÄra SÅ«tra says:
Existence and non-existence are both extremes, up to the range of the mind;
When the range of the mind ceases, it is called the correct cessation of the mind.
The commentary says:
In this way, one does not cling to having a self-nature, nor does one cling to having no self-nature.
If a dharma has no self-nature, then there is nothing that can be done.
Moreover, as a verse says:
Denying existence is not non-existence, because non-existence is not grasped;
Just as denying blue is not blue, it is not wished to be said to be white.
The commentary says:
These two kinds of views are called unwholesome.
Therefore, one who has wisdom, who wishes to put an end to disputes and attain the bliss of nirvÄá¹‡a, should definitely refute these two kinds of evil views.
What is this again?

Whether included in the three realms or supramundane, whether wholesome, unwholesome, or indeterminate, all activities in the conventional sense, if they had intrinsic nature in the ultimate sense, then the exertion of effort to perform wholesome or unwholesome actions would be in vain and fruitless.
Why is this?
Because they already exist.
It is like a pot or cloth that already exists.

In this way, one who is happy would always be happy, and one who is suffering would always suffer, just like the colors and shapes painted on a wall do not change. All sentient beings would also be like this.

Moreover, if there is no intrinsic nature, then the exertion of effort to give rise to wholesome or unwholesome dharmas included in the three realms or supramundane would be in vain and fruitless, because they do not exist. In this way, the world would fall into annihilation, just like polishing a rabbit's horns to make them sharp is ultimately unobtainable.
Therefore, it is said in the verse:
Those of little wisdom see dharmas as either existent or non-existent, etc.,ğŸ”½Here is the corrected and aligned text:
That person will not see, the cessation of views, the ultimate truth.

Existence is one extreme, non-existence is another extreme.
In this way, the internal earth element and the external earth element are both devoid of duality.
The Buddhas, TathÄgatas, realize and attain perfect enlightenment through the wisdom of reality, without duality, with a single characteristic, which is to say, without characteristics.

And as a verse states:

If one is able to know in this way, one will attain liberation in the world.
Such sÅ«tras should be explained in detail here.
The commentary on the chapter on contemplating the six elements is completed.
